PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  A  PPTA  is  required  to  develop  the  project.  It  will  conduct  due  diligence  covering 
technical, economic, financial, governance, procurement, and anticorruption aspects, including 
social and environmental safeguards, and gender action plan on the proposed project; and 
operation, maintenance and capacity strengthening program for the utility including customers.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement 
3.  The PPTA is estimated to cost $0.5 million equivalent which will be financed on a grant 
basis  by  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  (JFPR),  and  administered  by  ADB.  The 
government counterpart support will be counterpart staff, office and housing accommodation, 
office supplies, secretarial assistance, domestic transportation, and other in-kind contributions. 
The value of government contribution is estimated to account for 10% of the total TA cost. The 
detailed cost estimate is presented in Table A4.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  The TA will require 16 person-months of international and 5 person months of national 
consulting inputs. ADB will hire a consulting firm in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use 
of  Consultants  by  ADB  and  its  Borrowers  (2013).  In  accordance  with  its  paragraph  2.31 
evaluation of the consulting entity qualifications will take into account possibility of downstream 
assignment (implementation of the investment project). Goods will be procured as per ADB’s 
Procurement  Guidelines  (2013). The  consulting firm  will  be  engaged  through fixed  budget 
selection  (FBS)  method,  due  to  the  specific  technological  complexity  of  the  project  using 
simplified technical proposal. The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in line with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (April 2010, as amended from time to time). 
Table A4.3 reflects required services.

5.  Electrical Power Grid/ Diesel Specialist and Project Team Leader (international, 4 
person-months).  Will  demonstrate  substantial  experience  developing  solar  power  projects 
(on/off-grid-connected), within context of remote areas and have following responsibilities: (i) 
Desk review of existing material/reports related to solar projects in the Cooks; work closely with 
the executing and implementing agencies, including the power utility to assess the status of 
existing  diesel  power  generators  and  solar  photovoltaic  grid  systems.  Conduct  renewable 
energy resource assessment, propose and select project sites for  the on-grid in the main

12  Appendix 4 
islands, and off-grid components in the outer islands across the northern and southern groups. 
Draft short project manual containing key information on how to implement the project. Conduct 
system simulations as needed. Deliverable 1: Inception Report. (ii) In coordination with the 
team and relevant stakeholders, conduct a network and synchronization assessment using 
appropriate  software  simulation  tools.  Conduct  diesel  fuel  usage  and  existing  load  profile 
analysis, including demand forecast. Key words: grid stability and compensation, integrated 
energy  matrix.  Balance  of  plant:  protection,  control,  monitoring,  synchronization,  power 
transformer and switchgear concept design; (iii) Conduct due diligence process for the selected 
project  sites  (technical,  economic,  social  and  environmental),  including  governance, 
anticorruption,  regulatory  and  policy  assessments;  (iv)  In  coordination  with  the  Financial 
Specialist, conduct techno-financial analysis, calculate Levelized Cost of Electricity. Design the 
procurement plan. Assess existing regulatory regime and structure for adequacy in including (or 
not)  feed  in  tariffs,  net  metering  for  rooftop  solar  PV,  incentives/  initiatives  for  facilitating 
deployment  of  solar  PV  power;  (v)  Lead  consultation  workshops  with  government,  non-
government stakeholders to assess system issues and discuss the proposed projects; (vi) 
Propose a concept on how the power utilities should be structured in order to enable new 
technologies to operate on a sustainable manner; (vii) Draft the due diligence report under 
guidance  of  the  Energy  Specialist,  PATE.    Exact  contents  will  be  determined  during  the 
inception  mission  but  will  include  site  description,  system  simulation,  technical  concept 
specifications, cost estimates, economic and financial feasibility, procurement plan, governance 
and new utility structure, risk assessment, environmental and social safeguards according to 
ADB principles; (viii) Conduct at least 2 stakeholder workshops in the main islands; Deliverable 
2:  Draft  Final  Report  (including  workshop  report);  Deliverable  3:  Board  support 
documentation (as needed); Deliverable 4: Draft Tender Documents, according to ADB’s 
guidelines.  
 
6.  Solar  Photovoltaic  (PV)  Power  Specialist  (international,  4  person-months).  Will 
demonstrate  substantial  experience  in  power  electric  systems  and  expertise  in  designing, 
implementing and commissioning distribution networks, power substations/ switch yards; both 
middle and low voltage switchgear, protection, control, automation and measurement. (i) Carry 
out preliminary resource assessments using satellite data and model expected output from the 
proposed grid-connected and off grid solar plants, including hybrid systems and mini grids, and 
select all project sites; (ii) Survey the existing electrical power systems and distribution (mini) 
grids in the selected project sites. Review existing grid code or similar for connecting larger 
quantities  of  solar  power  and  make  recommendations  on  remedies;  (iii)  Conduct  system 
simulations and design all solar generators, including configuration of power electronics and 
balance of plant/system; (iv) In coordination with the Team Leader, conduct network study, grid 
synchronization analysis, conduct fuel usage and existing load profile analysis; key words: grid 
stability  and  compensation,  integrated  energy  matrix,  protection,  control,  monitoring,  and 
switchgear/grid  design,  SCADA  power  transformer  and  switchgear.  Document  current  and 
future electricity demand and load curves for the grids. Elaborate technical calculations; (v) 
Prepare and confirm detailed cost estimates for the distribution network/ mini-grid (including 
solar power) scheme. The prices determined shall reflect the realistic cost of equipment to be 
sourced from prospective suppliers and contractors and take into account the procurement 
method and local procurement capacity; (vi) Assist the Project Team Leader in drafting all 
deliverables and conducting workshops. 
 
7.  Electrical  Power  (Battery)  Specialist  (international,  4  person-months).  Will 
demonstrate  substantial  experience  in  power  electric  systems  and  expertise  in  designing, 
implementing  and  commissioning  battery  storage  systems;  distribution  networks;  power 
substations/ switch yards (both middle and low voltage switchgear), including protection, control,

automation and measurement. (i) Undertake a market assessment of most suitable battery 
storage  and  control  technologies  (including  correspondent  protection  and  monitoring 
mechanisms) for the power systems, in order to facilitate load management including peak 
shaving and energy efficiency and support high levels of renewable energy penetration in the 
islands particularly for phased transition to 100% renewable energy on the outer islands; (ii) 
Compare technologies and conduct cost benefit analysis of best suitable options; (iii) Propose a 
concept for battery storage in mini-grids, and a concept for battery storage in the main island 
grid  including  governor  topology;  (iv)  Design  procurement  selection  criteria  and  technical 
schedules for battery and control system (including protection, monitoring and measurement). 
 
8.  Financial  Specialist  (Power)  (international,  2  person-months).  Will  demonstrate 
substantial experience in conventional generation and solar photovoltaic generation of electricity 
projects related to their financial appraisal and modeling. (i) Prepare cost estimates for the solar 
power schemes, including power demand, least-cost, sensitivity and risk analysis, EIRR, FIRR, 
WACC and calculate the LCOE, including O&M and equipment replacement parts for the whole 
project life cycle. ADB’s Handbook for Integrating Risk Analysis in the Economic Analysis of 
Projects,  will  provide  guidance;  (ii)  Incorporate  into  the  economic  analysis  the  economic 
quantification of environmental impact caused by the project (if any) following ADB’s Economic 
Valuation  of  Environmental  Impacts:  A  Workbook  (1996),  and  Environmental  Assessment 
Guidelines (2003); (iii) Assess the impact of the project on the uniform national power tariff in 
The Cook Islands and make recommendations to Government (if suitable) to create a sinking 
fund to ensure capital replacement at the end of the plants’ useful life; (iv) Assess regulatory 
framework for power tariff, including possibility of using project fuel savings to benefit poorer 
households or community service obligations; (v) Review audited financial statements of the 
implementing agency and/or utility to assess financial performance and internal generation of 
funds; (vi) conduct an assessment of the financial management capacity and internal control 
policies and procedures of executing and implementing agencies, based on ADB’s Guidelines 
on the Financial Management and Analysis of Projects (2005). 
 
9.  Social Specialist (international/individual, 1 person-month). Will strong background in 
social  analysis.  (i)  Conduct  surveys  and  consultations  with  Government  and  NGO’s  to 
supplement secondary data; stakeholder consultation activities (community leaders, elderly, 
disabled, women, etc.). Prepare poverty profile; safeguard corrective action plan; (ii) Conduct a 
social compliance audit for the existing facilities to identify past or present concerns related to 
impacts  on  land  acquisition/resettlement  or  indigenous  peoples  in  accordance  to  ADB 
Safeguard Policy Statement. (iii) Conduct poverty analysis and pro-poor impacts within the 
project area. Present findings in the Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy template; 
(iv) Identify gender issues, suggest remediation measures and incorporate them into the project 
design. Prepare and integrate the Gender Action Plan into the PAM; (v) Impact on indigenous 
peoples, and prepare an indigenous peoples plan (if any), following ADB’s Safeguard Policy 
Statement; (vi) Investigate land acquisition, use, and access; and natural resources. Undertake 
necessary due diligence/assessment and prepare a resettlement plan (RP) based on census of 
affected/displaced people (DPs), inventory of losses, and socio-economic survey of DPs, review 
of the country safeguard systems and identification on necessary measures in accordance with 
ADB's SPS. The contents of RP should follow the outline in Appendix 2 of the SPS. 
  
10.  Environment  Specialist  (international,  1  person-month).  With  strong  background 
related to power projects, or environmental assessment of infrastructure projects. (i) Prepare the 
environmental assessment for the project in accordance with local and ADB’s Safeguard Policy 
Statement (2009); (ii) Draft (i) Gantt Matrix focusing on energy, technology, environment, social, 
legal, and economic aspects; (iii) listing of impacts on soil, air and water and relevant mitigation

of the institutional capacity of the Project proponent, relevant regulatory agencies involved with

building; (vii) draft initial environmental examination and environmental management plan, in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009);  (ii)  environmental  text  for  the 
Project Administration Manual, including detailed activities, and (iii) draft environment text for

11.  National Support Project Management Consultant (Generalist: technical or social 5 
person-months). (i) Assist the Project Team in gathering existing background data and reports; 
(ii)  assist  the  project  team  in  (a)  arranging  travel  logistics,  (b)  arranging  meetings  and 
workshops,  (c)  maintaining  contacts  with  stakeholders,  (d)  obtaining  relevant  country 
background data, and (e) obtaining follow-up technical data; (iii) support the Government in 
coordinating and implementing TA activities; (iv) Community facilitator: during communication 
and  consultations  between  team,  government  and  community;  preparation  of  technical 
specifications and feasibility studies; implementing workshops and dissemination activities 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  The Ministry of Finance and Economic Management (MOFEM) will act as the executing 
agency. The TAU and APS will be the implementing agencies supervised and coordinated by 
the OEC and will have overall responsibility for implementing the projects. The TAU and APS 
have adequate capacity in engineering and power system planning, finance, environment, and 
social areas. The CIIC will be the owner of all assets generated by the projects. The PPTA is 
envisaged to be implemented between September 2013 and April 2014, as scheduled in Table 
4.4.
